text: In common usage, climate change describes global warming—the ongoing increase in global average temperature—and its effects on Earth's climate system
label: Climate Change

text: Climate change in a broader sense also includes previous long-term changes to Earth's climate
label: Climate Change

text: The current rise in global average temperature is primarily caused by humans burning fossil fuels since the Industrial Revolution
label: Climate Change

text: Fossil fuel use, deforestation, and some agricultural and industrial practices add to greenhouse gases
label: Climate Change

text: These gases absorb some of the heat that the Earth radiates after it warms from sunlight, warming the lower atmosphere
label: Climate Change

text:
Carbon dioxide, the primary greenhouse gas driving global warming, has grown by about 50% and is at levels unseen for millions of years.
Climate change has an increasingly large impact on the environment
label: Climate Change

text: Deserts are expanding, while heat waves and wildfires are becoming more common
label: Climate Change

text: Amplified warming in the Arctic has contributed to thawing permafrost, retreat of glaciers and sea ice decline
label: Climate Change

text: Higher temperatures are also causing more intense storms, droughts, and other weather extremes
label: Climate Change

text: Rapid environmental change in mountains, coral reefs, and the Arctic is forcing many species to relocate or become extinct
label: Climate Change

text: Even if efforts to minimize future warming are successful, some effects will continue for centuries
label: Climate Change

text:
These include ocean heating, ocean acidification and sea level rise.
Climate change threatens people with increased flooding, extreme heat, increased food and water scarcity, more disease, and economic loss
label: Climate Change

text: The World Health Organization calls climate change one of the biggest threats to global health in the 21st century
label: Climate Change

text: Societies and ecosystems will experience more severe risks without action to limit warming
label: Climate Change

text: Adapting to climate change through efforts like flood control measures or drought-resistant crops partially reduces climate change risks, although some limits to adaptation have already been reached
label: Climate Change

text:
Poorer communities are responsible for a small share of global emissions, yet have the least ability to adapt and are most vulnerable to climate change.

Many climate change impacts have been felt in recent years, with 2023 the warmest on record at +1.48 °C (2.66 °F) since regular tracking began in 1850
label: Climate Change

text: Additional warming will increase these impacts and can trigger tipping points, such as melting all of the Greenland ice sheet
label: Climate Change

text: Under the 2015 Paris Agreement, nations collectively agreed to keep warming "well under 2 °C"
label: Climate Change

text: However, with pledges made under the Agreement, global warming would still reach about 2.7 °C (4.9 °F) by the end of the century
label: Climate Change

text:
Limiting warming to 1.5 °C would require halving emissions by 2030 and achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.
Fossil fuel use can be phased out by conserving energy and switching to energy sources that do not produce significant carbon pollution
label: Climate Change

text: These energy sources include wind, solar, hydro, and nuclear power
label: Climate Change

text: Cleanly generated electricity can replace fossil fuels for powering transportation, heating buildings, and running industrial processes
label: Climate Change

text:
Carbon can also be removed from the atmosphere, for instance by increasing forest cover and farming with methods that capture carbon in soil.


== Terminology ==
Before the 1980s it was unclear whether the warming effect of increased greenhouse gases was stronger than the cooling effect of airborne particulates in air pollution
label: Climate Change

text: Scientists used the term inadvertent climate modification to refer to human impacts on the climate at this time
label: Climate Change

text: In the 1980s, the terms global warming and climate change became more common, often being used interchangeably
label: Climate Change

text:
Scientifically, global warming refers only to increased surface warming, while climate change describes both global warming and its effects on Earth's climate system, such as precipitation changes.
Climate change can also be used more broadly to include changes to the climate that have happened throughout Earth's history
label: Climate Change

text: Global warming—used as early as 1975—became the more popular term after NASA climate scientist James Hansen used it in his 1988 testimony in the U.S
label: Climate Change

text:
Various scientists, politicians and media may use the terms climate crisis or climate emergency to talk about climate change, and may use the term global heating instead of global warming.


== Global temperature rise ==


=== Temperature records prior to global warming ===

Over the last few million years human beings evolved in a climate that cycled through ice ages, with global average temperature ranging between 1 °C warmer and 5–6 °C colder than current levels
label: Climate Change

text: One of the hotter periods was the Last Interglacial between 115,000 and 130,000 years ago, when sea levels were 6 to 9 metres higher than today
label: Climate Change

text:
The most recent glacial maximum 20,000 years ago had sea levels that were about 125 metres (410 ft) lower than today.
Temperatures stabilized in the current interglacial period beginning 11,700 years ago
label: Climate Change

text: Historical patterns of warming and cooling, like the Medieval Warm Period and the Little Ice Age, did not occur at the same time across different regions
label: Climate Change

text: Temperatures may have reached as high as those of the late 20th century in a limited set of regions
label: Climate Change

text:
Climate information for that period comes from climate proxies, such as trees and ice cores.


=== Warming since the Industrial Revolution ===

Around 1850 thermometer records began to provide global coverage.
Between the 18th century and 1970 there was little net warming, as the warming impact of greenhouse gas emissions was offset by cooling from sulfur dioxide emissions
label: Climate Change

text: Sulfur dioxide causes acid rain, but it also produces sulfate aerosols in the atmosphere, which reflect sunlight and cause so-called global dimming
label: Climate Change

text:
After 1970, the increasing accumulation of greenhouse gases and controls on sulfur pollution led to a marked increase in temperature.
Ongoing changes in climate have had no precedent for several thousand years
label: Climate Change

text: Multiple independent datasets all show worldwide increases in surface temperature, at a rate of around 0.2 °C per decade
label: Climate Change

text: The 2013–2022 decade warmed to an average 1.15 °C [1.00–1.25 °C] compared to the pre-industrial baseline (1850–1900)
label: Climate Change

text: Not every single year was warmer than the last: internal climate variability processes can make any year 0.2 °C warmer or colder than the average
label: Climate Change

text: From 1998 to 2013, negative phases of two such processes, Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO) and Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO) caused a so-called "global warming hiatus"
label: Climate Change

text: After the hiatus, the opposite occurred, with years like 2023 exhibiting temperatures well above even the recent average
label: Climate Change

text:
This is why the temperature change is defined in terms of a 20-year average, which reduces the noise of hot and cold years and decadal climate patterns, and detects the long-term signal.: 5 
A wide range of other observations reinforce the evidence of warming
label: Climate Change

text: The upper atmosphere is cooling, because greenhouse gases are trapping heat near the Earth's surface, and so less heat is radiating into space
label: Climate Change

text: Warming reduces average snow cover and forces the retreat of glaciers
label: Climate Change

text: At the same time, warming also causes greater evaporation from the oceans, leading to more atmospheric humidity, more and heavier precipitation
label: Climate Change

text:
Plants are flowering earlier in spring, and thousands of animal species have been permanently moving to cooler areas.


==== Differences by region ====
Different regions of the world warm at different rates
label: Climate Change

text: The pattern is independent of where greenhouse gases are emitted, because the gases persist long enough to diffuse across the planet
label: Climate Change

text: Since the pre-industrial period, the average surface temperature over land regions has increased almost twice as fast as the global average surface temperature
label: Climate Change

text: This is because oceans lose more heat by evaporation and oceans can store a lot of heat
label: Climate Change

text: The thermal energy in the global climate system has grown with only brief pauses since at least 1970, and over 90% of this extra energy has been stored in the ocean
label: Climate Change

text:
The rest has heated the atmosphere, melted ice, and warmed the continents.
The Northern Hemisphere and the North Pole have warmed much faster than the South Pole and Southern Hemisphere
label: Climate Change

text: The Northern Hemisphere not only has much more land, but also more seasonal snow cover and sea ice
label: Climate Change

text: As these surfaces flip from reflecting a lot of light to being dark after the ice has melted, they start absorbing more heat
label: Climate Change

text: Local black carbon deposits on snow and ice also contribute to Arctic warming
label: Climate Change

text: Arctic surface temperatures are increasing between three and four times faster than in the rest of the world
label: Climate Change

text:
Melting of ice sheets near the poles weakens both the Atlantic and the Antarctic limb of thermohaline circulation, which further changes the distribution of heat and precipitation around the globe.


=== Future global temperatures ===

The World Meteorological Organization estimates a 66% chance of global temperatures exceeding 1.5 °C warming from the preindustrial baseline for at least one year between 2023 and 2027
label: Climate Change

text:
Because the IPCC uses a 20-year average to define global temperature changes, a single year exceeding 1.5 °C does not break the limit.
The IPCC expects the 20-year average global temperature to exceed +1.5 °C in the early 2030s
label: Climate Change

text:
The IPCC Sixth Assessment Report (2023) included projections that by 2100 global warming is very likely to reach 1.0-1.8 °C under a scenario with very low emissions of greenhouse gases, 2.1-3.5 °C under an intermediate emissions scenario,
or 3.3-5.7 °C under a very high emissions scenario
label: Climate Change

text:
The warming will continue past 2100 in the intermediate and high emission scenarios, with future projections of global surface temperatures by year 2300 being similar to millions of years ago.
The remaining carbon budget for staying beneath certain temperature increases is determined by modelling the carbon cycle and climate sensitivity to greenhouse gases
label: Climate Change

text: According to the IPCC, global warming can be kept below 1.5 °C with a two-thirds chance if emissions after 2018 do not exceed 420 or 570 gigatonnes of CO2
label: Climate Change

text: This corresponds to 10 to 13 years of current emissions
label: Climate Change

text: For instance, it may be 100 gigatonnes of CO2 equivalent smaller due to CO2 and methane release from permafrost and wetlands
label: Climate Change

text: However, it is clear that fossil fuel resources need to be proactively kept in the ground to prevent substantial warming
label: Climate Change

text:
Otherwise, their shortages would not occur until the emissions have already locked in significant long-term impacts.


== Causes of recent global temperature rise ==

The climate system experiences various cycles on its own which can last for years, decades or even centuries
label: Climate Change

text: For example, El Niño events cause short-term spikes in surface temperature while La Niña events cause short term cooling
label: Climate Change

text: Their relative frequency can affect global temperature trends on a decadal timescale
label: Climate Change

text: Other changes are caused by an imbalance of energy from external forcings
label: Climate Change

text:
Examples of these include changes in the concentrations of greenhouse gases, solar luminosity, volcanic eruptions, and variations in the Earth's orbit around the Sun.
To determine the human contribution to climate change, unique "fingerprints" for all potential causes are developed and compared with both observed patterns and known internal climate variability
label: Climate Change

text: For example, solar forcing—whose fingerprint involves warming the entire atmosphere—is ruled out because only the lower atmosphere has warmed
label: Climate Change

text:
Other drivers, such as changes in albedo, are less impactful.


=== Greenhouse gases ===

Greenhouse gases are transparent to sunlight, and thus allow it to pass through the atmosphere to heat the Earth's surface
label: Climate Change

text: The Earth radiates it as heat, and greenhouse gases absorb a portion of it
label: Climate Change

text:
This absorption slows the rate at which heat escapes into space, trapping heat near the Earth's surface and warming it over time.
While water vapour (≈50%) and clouds (≈25%) are the biggest contributors to the greenhouse effect, they primarily change as a function of temperature and are therefore mostly considered to be feedbacks that change climate sensitivity
label: Climate Change

text:
On the other hand, concentrations of gases such as CO2 (≈20%), tropospheric ozone, CFCs and nitrous oxide are added or removed independently from temperature, and are therefore considered to be external forcings that change global temperatures.
Before the Industrial Revolution, naturally-occurring amounts of greenhouse gases caused the air near the surface to be about 33 °C warmer than it would have been in their absence
label: Climate Change

text: Human activity since the Industrial Revolution, mainly extracting and burning fossil fuels (coal, oil, and natural gas), has increased the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, resulting in a radiative imbalance
label: Climate Change

text: In 2019, the concentrations of CO2 and methane had increased by about 48% and 160%, respectively, since 1750
label: Climate Change

text: These CO2 levels are higher than they have been at any time during the last 2 million years
label: Climate Change

text:
Concentrations of methane are far higher than they were over the last 800,000 years.

Global anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions in 2019 were equivalent to 59 billion tonnes of CO2
label: Climate Change

text: Of these emissions, 75% was CO2, 18% was methane, 4% was nitrous oxide, and 2% was fluorinated gases
label: Climate Change

text: CO2 emissions primarily come from burning fossil fuels to provide energy for transport, manufacturing, heating, and electricity
label: Climate Change

text: Additional CO2 emissions come from deforestation and industrial processes, which include the CO2 released by the chemical reactions for making cement, steel, aluminum, and fertilizer
label: Climate Change

text: Methane emissions come from livestock, manure, rice cultivation, landfills, wastewater, and coal mining, as well as oil and gas extraction
label: Climate Change

text:
Nitrous oxide emissions largely come from the microbial decomposition of fertilizer.
While methane only lasts in the atmosphere for an average of 12 years, CO2 lasts much longer
label: Climate Change

text: The Earth's surface absorbs CO2 as part of the carbon cycle
label: Climate Change

text: While plants on land and in the ocean absorb most excess emissions of CO2 every year, that CO2 is returned to the atmosphere when biological matter is digested, burns, or decays
label: Climate Change

text: Land-surface carbon sink processes, such as carbon fixation in the soil and photosynthesis, remove about 29% of annual global CO2 emissions
label: Climate Change

text: The ocean has absorbed 20 to 30% of emitted CO2 over the last 2 decades
label: Climate Change

text:
CO2 is only removed from the atmosphere for the long term when it is stored in the Earth's crust, which is a process that can take millions of years to complete.


=== Land surface changes ===

According to Food and Agriculture Organization, around 30% of Earth's land area is largely unusable for humans (glaciers, deserts, etc.), 26% is forests, 10% is shrubland and 34% is agricultural land
label: Climate Change

text: Deforestation is the main land use change contributor to global warming, as the destroyed trees release CO2, and are not replaced by new trees, removing that carbon sink
label: Climate Change

text: Between 2001 and 2018, 27% of deforestation was from permanent clearing to enable agricultural expansion for crops and livestock
label: Climate Change

text: Another 24% has been lost to temporary clearing under the shifting cultivation agricultural systems
label: Climate Change

text: 26% was due to logging for wood and derived products, and wildfires have accounted for the remaining 23%
label: Climate Change

text: Some forests have not been fully cleared, but were already degraded by these impacts
label: Climate Change

text:
Restoring these forests also recovers their potential as a carbon sink.
Local vegetation cover impacts how much of the sunlight gets reflected back into space (albedo), and how much heat is lost by evaporation
label: Climate Change

text: For instance, the change from a dark forest to grassland makes the surface lighter, causing it to reflect more sunlight
label: Climate Change

text: Deforestation can also modify the release of chemical compounds that influence clouds, and by changing wind patterns
label: Climate Change

text: In tropic and temperate areas the net effect is to produce significant warming, and forest restoration can make local temperatures cooler
label: Climate Change

text: At latitudes closer to the poles, there is a cooling effect as forest is replaced by snow-covered (and more reflective) plains
label: Climate Change

text: Globally, these increases in surface albedo have been the dominant direct influence on temperature from land use change
label: Climate Change

text:
Thus, land use change to date is estimated to have a slight cooling effect.


=== Other factors ===


==== Aerosols and clouds ====
Air pollution, in the form of aerosols, affects the climate on a large scale
label: Climate Change

text: From 1961 to 1990, a gradual reduction in the amount of sunlight reaching the Earth's surface was observed
label: Climate Change

text: This phenomenon is popularly known as global dimming, and is primarily attributed to sulfate aerosols produced by the combustion of fossil fuels with heavy sulfur concentrations like coal and bunker fuel
label: Climate Change

text: Smaller contributions come from black carbon, organic carbon from combustion of fossil fuels and biofuels, and from anthropogenic dust
label: Climate Change

text:
Globally, aerosols have been declining since 1990 due to pollution controls, meaning that they no longer mask greenhouse gas warming as much.
Aerosols also have indirect effects on the Earth's energy budget
label: Climate Change

text: Sulfate aerosols act as cloud condensation nuclei and lead to clouds that have more and smaller cloud droplets
label: Climate Change

text: These clouds reflect solar radiation more efficiently than clouds with fewer and larger droplets
label: Climate Change

text: They also reduce the growth of raindrops, which makes clouds more reflective to incoming sunlight
label: Climate Change

text:
Indirect effects of aerosols are the largest uncertainty in radiative forcing.
While aerosols typically limit global warming by reflecting sunlight, black carbon in soot that falls on snow or ice can contribute to global warming
label: Climate Change

text: Not only does this increase the absorption of sunlight, it also increases melting and sea-level rise
label: Climate Change

text: Limiting new black carbon deposits in the Arctic could reduce global warming by 0.2 °C by 2050
label: Climate Change

text:
The effect of decreasing sulfur content of fuel oil for ships since 2020 is estimated to cause an additional 0.05 °C increase in global mean temperature by 2050.


==== Solar and volcanic activity ====

As the Sun is the Earth's primary energy source, changes in incoming sunlight directly affect the climate system
label: Climate Change

text: Solar irradiance has been measured directly by satellites, and indirect measurements are available from the early 1600s onwards
label: Climate Change

text: Since 1880, there has been no upward trend in the amount of the Sun's energy reaching the Earth, in contrast to the warming of the lower atmosphere (the troposphere)
label: Climate Change

text:
The upper atmosphere (the stratosphere) would also be warming if the Sun was sending more energy to Earth, but instead, it has been cooling.
This is consistent with greenhouse gases preventing heat from leaving the Earth's atmosphere.
Explosive volcanic eruptions can release gases, dust and ash that partially block sunlight and reduce temperatures, or they can send water vapour into the atmosphere, which adds to greenhouse gases and increases temperatures
label: Climate Change

text: These impacts on temperature only last for several years, because both water vapour and volcanic material have low persistence in the atmosphere
label: Climate Change

text: volcanic CO2 emissions are more persistent, but they are equivalent to less than 1% of current human-caused CO2 emissions
label: Climate Change

text: Volcanic activity still represents the single largest natural impact (forcing) on temperature in the industrial era
label: Climate Change

text:
Yet, like the other natural forcings, it has had negligible impacts on global temperature trends since the Industrial Revolution.


==== Climate change feedbacks ====

The response of the climate system to an initial forcing is modified by feedbacks: increased by "self-reinforcing" or "positive" feedbacks and reduced by "balancing" or "negative" feedbacks
label: Climate Change

text: The main reinforcing feedbacks are the water-vapour feedback, the ice–albedo feedback, and the net effect of clouds
label: Climate Change

text: The primary balancing mechanism is radiative cooling, as Earth's surface gives off more heat to space in response to rising temperature
label: Climate Change

text: In addition to temperature feedbacks, there are feedbacks in the carbon cycle, such as the fertilizing effect of CO2 on plant growth
label: Climate Change

text:
Feedbacks are expected to trend in a positive direction as greenhouse gas emissions continue, raising climate sensitivity.
Radiative feedbacks are physical processes that influence the rate of global warming in response to warming
label: Climate Change

text: For instance, warmer air can hold more moisture, and water vapour itself is a potent greenhouse gas
label: Climate Change

text: Warmer air can also result in clouds becoming higher and thinner, where they act as an insulator and warm the planet
label: Climate Change

text: Another major feedback is the reduction of snow cover and sea ice in the Arctic, reducing the reflectivity of the Earth's surface there and contributing to amplification of Arctic temperature changes
label: Climate Change

text:
Arctic amplification is also thawing permafrost, which releases methane and CO2 into the atmosphere.
Around half of human-caused CO2 emissions have been absorbed by land plants and by the oceans
label: Climate Change

text: This fraction is not static and if future CO2 emissions decrease, the Earth will be able to absorb up to around 70%
label: Climate Change

text: If they increase substantially, it'll still absorb more carbon than now, but the overall fraction will decrease to below 40%
label: Climate Change

text: This is because climate change increases droughts and heat waves that eventually inhibit plant growth on land, and soils will release more carbon from dead plants when they are warmer
label: Climate Change

text: The rate at which oceans absorb atmospheric carbon will be lowered as they become more acidic and experience changes in thermohaline circulation and phytoplankton distribution
label: Climate Change

text:
Uncertainty over feedbacks, particularly cloud cover, is the major reason why different climate models project different magnitudes of warming for a given amount of emissions.


== Modelling ==

A climate model is a representation of the physical, chemical and biological processes that affect the climate system
label: Climate Change

text: Models include natural processes like changes in the Earth's orbit, historical changes in the Sun's activity, and volcanic forcing
label: Climate Change

text: Models are used to estimate the degree of warming future emissions will cause when accounting for the strength of climate feedbacks
label: Climate Change

text:
Models also predict the circulation of the oceans, the annual cycle of the seasons, and the flows of carbon between the land surface and the atmosphere.
The physical realism of models is tested by examining their ability to simulate current or past climates
label: Climate Change

text: Past models have underestimated the rate of Arctic shrinkage and underestimated the rate of precipitation increase
label: Climate Change

text: Sea level rise since 1990 was underestimated in older models, but more recent models agree well with observations
label: Climate Change

text: The 2017 United States-published National Climate Assessment notes that "climate models may still be underestimating or missing relevant feedback processes"
label: Climate Change

text:
Additionally, climate models may be unable to adequately predict short-term regional climatic shifts.
A subset of climate models add societal factors to a physical climate model
label: Climate Change

text: These models simulate how population, economic growth, and energy use affect—and interact with—the physical climate
label: Climate Change

text: With this information, these models can produce scenarios of future greenhouse gas emissions
label: Climate Change

text: This is then used as input for physical climate models and carbon cycle models to predict how atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases might change
label: Climate Change

text:
Depending on the socioeconomic scenario and the mitigation scenario, models produce atmospheric CO2 concentrations that range widely between 380 and 1400 ppm.


== Impacts ==


=== Environmental effects ===

The environmental effects of climate change are broad and far-reaching, affecting oceans, ice, and weather
label: Climate Change

text: Evidence for these effects comes from studying climate change in the past, from modelling, and from modern observations
label: Climate Change

text: Since the 1950s, droughts and heat waves have appeared simultaneously with increasing frequency
label: Climate Change

text: Extremely wet or dry events within the monsoon period have increased in India and East Asia
label: Climate Change

text: Monsoonal precipitation over the Northern Hemisphere has increased since 1980
label: Climate Change

text: The rainfall rate and intensity of hurricanes and typhoons is likely increasing, and the geographic range likely expanding poleward in response to climate warming
label: Climate Change

text:
Frequency of tropical cyclones has not increased as a result of climate change.

Global sea level is rising as a consequence of thermal expansion and the melting of glaciers and ice sheets
label: Climate Change

text: Between 1993 and 2020, the rise increased over time, averaging 3.3 ± 0.3 mm per year
label: Climate Change

text: Over the 21st century, the IPCC projects 32–62 cm of sea level rise under a low emission scenario, 44–76 cm under an intermediate one and 65–101 cm under a very high emission scenario
label: Climate Change

text:
Marine ice sheet instability processes in Antarctica may add substantially to these values, including the possibility of a 2-meter sea level rise by 2100 under high emissions.
Climate change has led to decades of shrinking and thinning of the Arctic sea ice
label: Climate Change

text: While ice-free summers are expected to be rare at 1.5 °C degrees of warming, they are set to occur once every three to ten years at a warming level of 2 °C
label: Climate Change

text: Higher atmospheric CO2 concentrations cause more CO2 to dissolve in the oceans, which is making them more acidic
label: Climate Change

text:
Because oxygen is less soluble in warmer water, its concentrations in the ocean are decreasing, and dead zones are expanding.


=== Tipping points and long-term impacts ===

Greater degrees of global warming increase the risk of passing through 'tipping points'—thresholds beyond which certain major impacts can no longer be avoided even if temperatures return to their previous state
label: Climate Change

text: For instance, the Greenland ice sheet is already melting, but if global warming reaches levels between 1.7 °C and 2.3 °C, its melting will continue until it fully disappears
label: Climate Change

text: If the warming is later reduced to 1.5 °C or less, it will still lose a lot more ice than if the warming was never allowed to reach the threshold in the first place
label: Climate Change

text: While the ice sheets would melt over millennia, other tipping points would occur faster and give societies less time to respond
label: Climate Change

text:
The collapse of major ocean currents like the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC), and irreversible damage to key ecosystems like the Amazon rainforest and coral reefs can unfold in a matter of decades.
The long-term effects of climate change on oceans include further ice melt, ocean warming, sea level rise, ocean acidification and ocean deoxygenation
label: Climate Change

text: The timescale of long-term impacts are centuries to millennia due to CO2's long atmospheric lifetime
label: Climate Change

text: When net emissions stabilize surface air temperatures will also stabilize, but oceans and ice caps will continue to absorb excess heat from the atmosphere
label: Climate Change

text: The result is an estimated total sea level rise of 2.3 metres per degree Celsius (4.2 ft/°F) after 2000 years
label: Climate Change

text: Oceanic CO2 uptake is slow enough that ocean acidification will also continue for hundreds to thousands of years
label: Climate Change

text: Deep oceans (below 2,000 metres (6,600 ft)) are also already committed to losing over 10% of their dissolved oxygen by the warming which occurred to date
label: Climate Change

text:
Further, the West Antarctic ice sheet appears committed to practically irreversible melting, which would increase the sea levels by at least 3.3 m (10 ft 10 in) over approximately 2000 years.


=== Nature and wildlife ===

Recent warming has driven many terrestrial and freshwater species poleward and towards higher altitudes
label: Climate Change

text: For instance, the range of hundreds of North American birds has shifted northward at an average rate of 1.5 km/year over the past 55 years
label: Climate Change

text: Higher atmospheric CO2 levels and an extended growing season have resulted in global greening
label: Climate Change

text: However, heatwaves and drought have reduced ecosystem productivity in some regions
label: Climate Change

text: A related phenomenon driven by climate change is woody plant encroachment, affecting up to 500 million hectares globally
label: Climate Change

text: Climate change has contributed to the expansion of drier climate zones, such as the expansion of deserts in the subtropics
label: Climate Change

text: The size and speed of global warming is making abrupt changes in ecosystems more likely
label: Climate Change

text:
Overall, it is expected that climate change will result in the extinction of many species.
The oceans have heated more slowly than the land, but plants and animals in the ocean have migrated towards the colder poles faster than species on land
label: Climate Change

text: Just as on land, heat waves in the ocean occur more frequently due to climate change, harming a wide range of organisms such as corals, kelp, and seabirds
label: Climate Change

text: Ocean acidification makes it harder for marine calcifying organisms such as mussels, barnacles and corals to produce shells and skeletons; and heatwaves have bleached coral reefs
label: Climate Change

text: Harmful algal blooms enhanced by climate change and eutrophication lower oxygen levels, disrupt food webs and cause great loss of marine life
label: Climate Change

text: Almost half of global wetlands have disappeared due to climate change and other human impacts
label: Climate Change

text:
Plants have come under increased stress from damage by insects.


=== Humans ===

The effects of climate change are impacting humans everywhere in the world
label: Climate Change

text: Impacts can be observed on all continents and ocean regions, with low-latitude, less developed areas facing the greatest risk
label: Climate Change

text: Continued warming has potentially "severe, pervasive and irreversible impacts" for people and ecosystems
label: Climate Change

text:
The risks are unevenly distributed, but are generally greater for disadvantaged people in developing and developed countries.


==== Health and food ====

The World Health Organization calls climate change one of the biggest threats to global health in the 21st century
label: Climate Change

text: Extreme weather events affect public health, and food and water security
label: Climate Change

text: Climate change increases the intensity and frequency of extreme weather events
label: Climate Change

text: It can affect transmission of infectious diseases, such as dengue fever and malaria
label: Climate Change

text: According to the World Economic Forum, 14.5 million more deaths are expected due to climate change by 2050
label: Climate Change

text: 30% of the global population currently live in areas where extreme heat and humidity are already associated with excess deaths
label: Climate Change

text:
By 2100, 50% to 75% of the global population would live in such areas.
While total crop yields have been increasing in the past 50 years due to agricultural improvements, climate change has already decreased the rate of yield growth
label: Climate Change

text: While agricultural productivity has been positively affected in some high latitude areas, mid- and low-latitude areas have been negatively affected
label: Climate Change

text: According to the World Economic Forum, an increase in drought in certain regions could cause 3.2 million deaths from malnutrition by 2050 and stunting in children
label: Climate Change

text: With 2 °C warming, global livestock headcounts could decline by 7–10% by 2050, as less animal feed will be available
label: Climate Change

text:
If the emissions continue to increase for the rest of century, then over 9 million climate-related deaths would occur annually by 2100.


==== Livelihoods and inequality ====

Economic damages due to climate change may be severe and there is a chance of disastrous consequences
label: Climate Change

text: Severe impacts are expected in South-East Asia and sub-Saharan Africa, where most of the local inhabitants are dependent upon natural and agricultural resources
label: Climate Change

text: If warming reaches 4 °C then labour capacity in those regions could be reduced by 30 to 50%
label: Climate Change

text:
The World Bank estimates that between 2016 and 2030, climate change could drive over 120 million people into extreme poverty without adaptation.
Inequalities based on wealth and social status have worsened due to climate change
label: Climate Change

text: Major difficulties in mitigating, adapting to, and recovering from climate shocks are faced by marginalized people who have less control over resources
label: Climate Change

text: Indigenous people, who are subsistent on their land and ecosystems, will face endangerment to their wellness and lifestyles due to climate change
label: Climate Change

text:
An expert elicitation concluded that the role of climate change in armed conflict has been small compared to factors such as socio-economic inequality and state capabilities.
While women are not inherently more at risk from climate change and shocks, limits on women's resources and discriminatory gender norms constrain their adaptive capacity and resilience
label: Climate Change

text:
For example, women's work burdens, including hours worked in agriculture, tend to decline less than men's during climate shocks such as heat stress.


==== Climate migration ====

Low-lying islands and coastal communities are threatened by sea level rise, which makes urban flooding more common
label: Climate Change

text: This could lead to statelessness for people in island nations, such as the Maldives and Tuvalu
label: Climate Change

text: In some regions, the rise in temperature and humidity may be too severe for humans to adapt to
label: Climate Change

text:
With worst-case climate change, models project that almost one-third of humanity might live in Sahara-like uninhabitable and extremely hot climates.
These factors can drive climate or environmental migration, within and between countries
label: Climate Change

text: More people are expected to be displaced because of sea level rise, extreme weather and conflict from increased competition over natural resources
label: Climate Change

text:
Climate change may also increase vulnerability, leading to "trapped populations" who are not able to move due to a lack of resources.


== Reducing and recapturing emissions ==

Climate change can be mitigated by reducing the rate at which greenhouse gases are emitted into the atmosphere, and by increasing the rate at which carbon dioxide is removed from the atmosphere
label: Climate Change

text: In order to limit global warming to less than 1.5 °C global greenhouse gas emissions needs to be net-zero by 2050, or by 2070 with a 2 °C target
label: Climate Change

text:
This requires far-reaching, systemic changes on an unprecedented scale in energy, land, cities, transport, buildings, and industry.
The United Nations Environment Programme estimates that countries need to triple their pledges under the Paris Agreement within the next decade to limit global warming to 2 °C
label: Climate Change

text: An even greater level of reduction is required to meet the 1.5 °C goal
label: Climate Change

text: With pledges made under the Paris Agreement as of October 2021, global warming would still have a 66% chance of reaching about 2.7 °C (range: 2.2–3.2 °C) by the end of the century
label: Climate Change

text:
Globally, limiting warming to 2 °C may result in higher economic benefits than economic costs.
Although there is no single pathway to limit global warming to 1.5 or 2 °C, most scenarios and strategies see a major increase in the use of renewable energy in combination with increased energy efficiency measures to generate the needed greenhouse gas reductions
label: Climate Change

text:
To reduce pressures on ecosystems and enhance their carbon sequestration capabilities, changes would also be necessary in agriculture and forestry, such as preventing deforestation and restoring natural ecosystems by reforestation.
Other approaches to mitigating climate change have a higher level of risk
label: Climate Change

text: Scenarios that limit global warming to 1.5 °C typically project the large-scale use of carbon dioxide removal methods over the 21st century
label: Climate Change

text: There are concerns, though, about over-reliance on these technologies, and environmental impacts
label: Climate Change

text: Solar radiation modification (SRM) is also a possible supplement to deep reductions in emissions
label: Climate Change

text:
However, SRM raises significant ethical and legal concerns, and the risks are imperfectly understood.


=== Clean energy ===

Renewable energy is key to limiting climate change
label: Climate Change

text: For decades, fossil fuels have accounted for roughly 80% of the world's energy use
label: Climate Change

text: The remaining share has been split between nuclear power and renewables (including hydropower, bioenergy, wind and solar power and geothermal energy)
label: Climate Change

text: Fossil fuel use is expected to peak in absolute terms prior to 2030 and then to decline, with coal use experiencing the sharpest reductions
label: Climate Change

text: Renewables represented 75% of all new electricity generation installed in 2019, nearly all solar and wind
label: Climate Change

text: Other forms of clean energy, such as nuclear and hydropower, currently have a larger share of the energy supply
label: Climate Change

text:
However, their future growth forecasts appear limited in comparison.
While solar panels and onshore wind are now among the cheapest forms of adding new power generation capacity in many locations, green energy policies are needed to achieve a rapid transition from fossil fuels to renewables
label: Climate Change

text: To achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, renewable energy would become the dominant form of electricity generation, rising to 85% or more by 2050 in some scenarios
label: Climate Change

text:
Investment in coal would be eliminated and coal use nearly phased out by 2050.
Electricity generated from renewable sources would also need to become the main energy source for heating and transport
label: Climate Change

text: Transport can switch away from internal combustion engine vehicles and towards electric vehicles, public transit, and active transport (cycling and walking)
label: Climate Change

text:
Heating could be increasingly decarbonized with technologies like heat pumps.
There are obstacles to the continued rapid growth of clean energy, including renewables
label: Climate Change

text: For wind and solar, there are environmental and land use concerns for new projects
label: Climate Change

text: Wind and solar also produce energy intermittently and with seasonal variability
label: Climate Change

text: Traditionally, hydro dams with reservoirs and conventional power plants have been used when variable energy production is low
label: Climate Change

text: Going forward, battery storage can be expanded, energy demand and supply can be matched, and long-distance transmission can smooth variability of renewable outputs
label: Climate Change

text: Bioenergy is often not carbon-neutral and may have negative consequences for food security
label: Climate Change

text: The growth of nuclear power is constrained by controversy around radioactive waste, nuclear weapon proliferation, and accidents
label: Climate Change

text:
Hydropower growth is limited by the fact that the best sites have been developed, and new projects are confronting increased social and environmental concerns.
Low-carbon energy improves human health by minimizing climate change as well as reducing air pollution deaths, which were estimated at 7 million annually in 2016
label: Climate Change

text: Meeting the Paris Agreement goals that limit warming to a 2 °C increase could save about a million of those lives per year by 2050, whereas limiting global warming to 1.5 °C could save millions and simultaneously increase energy security and reduce poverty
label: Climate Change

text:
Improving air quality also has economic benefits which may be larger than mitigation costs.


=== Energy conservation ===

Reducing energy demand is another major aspect of reducing emissions
label: Climate Change

text: If less energy is needed, there is more flexibility for clean energy development
label: Climate Change

text: It also makes it easier to manage the electricity grid, and minimizes carbon-intensive infrastructure development
label: Climate Change

text: Major increases in energy efficiency investment will be required to achieve climate goals, comparable to the level of investment in renewable energy
label: Climate Change

text:
Several COVID-19 related changes in energy use patterns, energy efficiency investments, and funding have made forecasts for this decade more difficult and uncertain.
Strategies to reduce energy demand vary by sector
label: Climate Change

text: In the transport sector, passengers and freight can switch to more efficient travel modes, such as buses and trains, or use electric vehicles
label: Climate Change

text: Industrial strategies to reduce energy demand include improving heating systems and motors, designing less energy-intensive products, and increasing product lifetimes
label: Climate Change

text: In the building sector the focus is on better design of new buildings, and higher levels of energy efficiency in retrofitting
label: Climate Change

text:
The use of technologies like heat pumps can also increase building energy efficiency.


=== Agriculture and industry ===

 Agriculture and forestry face a triple challenge of limiting greenhouse gas emissions, preventing the further conversion of forests to agricultural land, and meeting increases in world food demand
label: Climate Change

text: A set of actions could reduce agriculture and forestry-based emissions by two thirds from 2010 levels
label: Climate Change

text:
These include reducing growth in demand for food and other agricultural products, increasing land productivity, protecting and restoring forests, and reducing greenhouse gas emissions from agricultural production.
On the demand side, a key component of reducing emissions is shifting people towards plant-based diets
label: Climate Change

text: Eliminating the production of livestock for meat and dairy would eliminate about 3/4ths of all emissions from agriculture and other land use
label: Climate Change

text:
Livestock also occupy 37% of ice-free land area on Earth and consume feed from the 12% of land area used for crops, driving deforestation and land degradation.
Steel and cement production are responsible for about 13% of industrial CO2 emissions
label: Climate Change

text:
In these industries, carbon-intensive materials such as coke and lime play an integral role in the production, so that reducing CO2 emissions requires research into alternative chemistries.


=== Carbon sequestration ===

Natural carbon sinks can be enhanced to sequester significantly larger amounts of CO2 beyond naturally occurring levels
label: Climate Change

text: Reforestation and afforestation (planting forests where there were none before) are among the most mature sequestration techniques, although the latter raises food security concerns
label: Climate Change

text: Farmers can promote sequestration of carbon in soils through practices such as use of winter cover crops, reducing the intensity and frequency of tillage, and using compost and manure as soil amendments
label: Climate Change

text: Forest and landscape restoration yields many benefits for the climate, including greenhouse gas emissions sequestration and reduction
label: Climate Change

text: Restoration/recreation of coastal wetlands, prairie plots and seagrass meadows increases the uptake of carbon into organic matter
label: Climate Change

text:
When carbon is sequestered in soils and in organic matter such as trees, there is a risk of the carbon being re-released into the atmosphere later through changes in land use, fire, or other changes in ecosystems.
Where energy production or CO2-intensive heavy industries continue to produce waste CO2, the gas can be captured and stored instead of released to the atmosphere
label: Climate Change

text: Although its current use is limited in scale and expensive, carbon capture and storage (CCS) may be able to play a significant role in limiting CO2 emissions by mid-century
label: Climate Change

text: This technique, in combination with bioenergy (BECCS) can result in net negative emissions as CO2 is drawn from the atmosphere
label: Climate Change

text: It remains highly uncertain whether carbon dioxide removal techniques will be able to play a large role in limiting warming to 1.5 °C
label: Climate Change

text:
Policy decisions that rely on carbon dioxide removal increase the risk of global warming rising beyond international goals.


== Adaptation ==

Adaptation is "the process of adjustment to current or expected changes in climate and its effects".: 5  Without additional mitigation, adaptation cannot avert the risk of "severe, widespread and irreversible" impacts
label: Climate Change

text: More severe climate change requires more transformative adaptation, which can be prohibitively expensive
label: Climate Change

text: The capacity and potential for humans to adapt is unevenly distributed across different regions and populations, and developing countries generally have less
label: Climate Change

text: The first two decades of the 21st century saw an increase in adaptive capacity in most low- and middle-income countries with improved access to basic sanitation and electricity, but progress is slow
label: Climate Change

text:
However, there is a considerable gap between necessary and available finance.
Adaptation to sea level rise consists of avoiding at-risk areas, learning to live with increased flooding, and building flood controls
label: Climate Change

text: Avoiding strenuous work or having air conditioning is not possible for everybody
label: Climate Change

text: In agriculture, adaptation options include a switch to more sustainable diets, diversification, erosion control, and genetic improvements for increased tolerance to a changing climate
label: Climate Change

text: Insurance allows for risk-sharing, but is often difficult to get for people on lower incomes
label: Climate Change

text: Education, migration and early warning systems can reduce climate vulnerability
label: Climate Change

text:
Planting mangroves or encouraging other coastal vegetation can buffer storms.
Ecosystems adapt to climate change, a process that can be supported by human intervention
label: Climate Change

text: By increasing connectivity between ecosystems, species can migrate to more favourable climate conditions
label: Climate Change

text: Species can also be introduced to areas acquiring a favourable climate
label: Climate Change

text: Protection and restoration of natural and semi-natural areas helps build resilience, making it easier for ecosystems to adapt
label: Climate Change

text: Many of the actions that promote adaptation in ecosystems, also help humans adapt via ecosystem-based adaptation
label: Climate Change

text: For instance, restoration of natural fire regimes makes catastrophic fires less likely, and reduces human exposure
label: Climate Change

text: Giving rivers more space allows for more water storage in the natural system, reducing flood risk
label: Climate Change

text:
Restored forest acts as a carbon sink, but planting trees in unsuitable regions can exacerbate climate impacts.
There are synergies but also trade-offs between adaptation and mitigation
label: Climate Change

text: An example for synergy is increased food productivity, which has large benefits for both adaptation and mitigation
label: Climate Change

text: An example of a trade-off is that increased use of air conditioning allows people to better cope with heat, but increases energy demand
label: Climate Change

text:
Another trade-off example is that more compact urban development may reduce emissions from transport and construction, but may also increase the urban heat island effect, exposing people to heat-related health risks.


== Policies and politics ==

Countries that are most vulnerable to climate change have typically been responsible for a small share of global emissions
label: Climate Change

text: Limiting global warming makes it much easier to achieve the UN's Sustainable Development Goals, such as eradicating poverty and reducing inequalities
label: Climate Change

text: The connection is recognized in Sustainable Development Goal 13 which is to "take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts"
label: Climate Change

text:
The goals on food, clean water and ecosystem protection have synergies with climate mitigation.
The geopolitics of climate change is complex
label: Climate Change

text: It has often been framed as a free-rider problem, in which all countries benefit from mitigation done by other countries, but individual countries would lose from switching to a low-carbon economy themselves
label: Climate Change

text: For instance, the benefits of a coal phase-out to public health and local environments exceed the costs in almost all regions
label: Climate Change

text:
Furthermore, net importers of fossil fuels win economically from switching to clean energy, causing net exporters to face stranded assets: fossil fuels they cannot sell.


=== Policy options ===
A wide range of policies, regulations, and laws are being used to reduce emissions
label: Climate Change

text: As of 2019, carbon pricing covers about 20% of global greenhouse gas emissions
label: Climate Change

text: Carbon can be priced with carbon taxes and emissions trading systems
label: Climate Change

text: Direct global fossil fuel subsidies reached $319 billion in 2017, and $5.2 trillion when indirect costs such as air pollution are priced in
label: Climate Change

text: Ending these can cause a 28% reduction in global carbon emissions and a 46% reduction in air pollution deaths
label: Climate Change

text: Money saved on fossil subsidies could be used to support the transition to clean energy instead
label: Climate Change

text: More direct methods to reduce greenhouse gases include vehicle efficiency standards, renewable fuel standards, and air pollution regulations on heavy industry
label: Climate Change

text:
Several countries require utilities to increase the share of renewables in power production.


==== Climate justice ====
Policy designed through the lens of climate justice tries to address human rights issues and social inequality
label: Climate Change

text: According to proponents of climate justice, the costs of climate adaptation should be paid by those most responsible for climate change, while the beneficiaries of payments should be those suffering impacts
label: Climate Change

text:
One way this can be addressed in practice is to have wealthy nations pay poorer countries to adapt.
Oxfam found that in 2023 the wealthiest 10% of people were responsible for 50% of global emissions, while the bottom 50% were responsible for just 8%
label: Climate Change

text: Production of emissions is another way to look at responsibility: under that approach, the top 21 fossil fuel companies would owe cumulative climate reparations of $5.4 trillion over the period 2025–2050
label: Climate Change

text:
To achieve a just transition, people working in the fossil fuel sector would also need other jobs, and their communities would need investments.


=== International climate agreements ===

Nearly all countries in the world are parties to the 1994 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
label: Climate Change

text: The goal of the UNFCCC is to prevent dangerous human interference with the climate system
label: Climate Change

text: As stated in the convention, this requires that greenhouse gas concentrations are stabilized in the atmosphere at a level where ecosystems can adapt naturally to climate change, food production is not threatened, and economic development can be sustained
label: Climate Change

text: The UNFCCC does not itself restrict emissions but rather provides a framework for protocols that do
label: Climate Change

text:
Its yearly conferences are the stage of global negotiations.
The 1997 Kyoto Protocol extended the UNFCCC and included legally binding commitments for most developed countries to limit their emissions
label: Climate Change

text: During the negotiations, the G77 (representing developing countries) pushed for a mandate requiring developed countries to "[take] the lead" in reducing their emissions, since developed countries contributed most to the accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere
label: Climate Change

text:
Per-capita emissions were also still relatively low in developing countries and developing countries would need to emit more to meet their development needs.
The 2009 Copenhagen Accord has been widely portrayed as disappointing because of its low goals, and was rejected by poorer nations including the G77
label: Climate Change

text: Associated parties aimed to limit the global temperature rise to below 2 °C
label: Climate Change

text: The Accord set the goal of sending $100 billion per year to developing countries for mitigation and adaptation by 2020, and proposed the founding of the Green Climate Fund
label: Climate Change

text:
Only in 2023 the target is expected to be achieved.
In 2015 all UN countries negotiated the Paris Agreement, which aims to keep global warming well below 2.0 °C and contains an aspirational goal of keeping warming under 1.5 °C
label: Climate Change

text: Unlike Kyoto, no binding emission targets were set in the Paris Agreement
label: Climate Change

text: Countries have to regularly set ever more ambitious goals and reevaluate these goals every five years
label: Climate Change

text: The Paris Agreement restated that developing countries must be financially supported
label: Climate Change

text:
As of October 2021, 194 states and the European Union have signed the treaty and 191 states and the EU have ratified or acceded to the agreement.
The 1987 Montreal Protocol, an international agreement to stop emitting ozone-depleting gases, may have been more effective at curbing greenhouse gas emissions than the Kyoto Protocol specifically designed to do so
label: Climate Change

text: The 2016 Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol aims to reduce the emissions of hydrofluorocarbons, a group of powerful greenhouse gases which served as a replacement for banned ozone-depleting gases
label: Climate Change

text:
This made the Montreal Protocol a stronger agreement against climate change.


=== National responses ===
In 2019, the United Kingdom parliament became the first national government to declare a climate emergency
label: Climate Change

text: That same year, the European Parliament declared a "climate and environmental emergency"
label: Climate Change

text: The European Commission presented its European Green Deal with the goal of making the EU carbon-neutral by 2050
label: Climate Change

text:
In 2021, the European Commission released its "Fit for 55" legislation package, which contains guidelines for the car industry; all new cars on the European market must be zero-emission vehicles from 2035.
Major countries in Asia have made similar pledges: South Korea and Japan have committed to become carbon-neutral by 2050, and China by 2060
label: Climate Change

text: While India has strong incentives for renewables, it also plans a significant expansion of coal in the country
label: Climate Change

text:
Vietnam is among very few coal-dependent, fast-developing countries that pledged to phase out unabated coal power by the 2040s or as soon as possible thereafter.
As of 2021, based on information from 48 national climate plans, which represent 40% of the parties to the Paris Agreement, estimated total greenhouse gas emissions will be 0.5% lower compared to 2010 levels, below the 45% or 25% reduction goals to limit global warming to 1.5 °C or 2 °C, respectively.


== Society ==


=== Denial and misinformation ===

Public debate about climate change has been strongly affected by climate change denial and misinformation, which originated in the United States and has since spread to other countries, particularly Canada and Australia
label: Climate Change

text: Climate change denial has originated from fossil fuel companies, industry groups, conservative think tanks, and contrarian scientists
label: Climate Change

text: Like the tobacco industry, the main strategy of these groups has been to manufacture doubt about climate-change related scientific data and results
label: Climate Change

text:
People who hold unwarranted doubt about climate change are called climate change "skeptics", although "contrarians" or "deniers" are more appropriate terms.
There are different variants of climate denial: some deny that warming takes place at all, some acknowledge warming but attribute it to natural influences, and some minimize the negative impacts of climate change
label: Climate Change

text: Manufacturing uncertainty about the science later developed into a manufactured controversy: creating the belief that there is significant uncertainty about climate change within the scientific community in order to delay policy changes
label: Climate Change

text: Strategies to promote these ideas include criticism of scientific institutions, and questioning the motives of individual scientists
label: Climate Change

text:
An echo chamber of climate-denying blogs and media has further fomented misunderstanding of climate change.


=== Public awareness and opinion ===

Climate change came to international public attention in the late 1980s
label: Climate Change

text: Due to media coverage in the early 1990s, people often confused climate change with other environmental issues like ozone depletion
label: Climate Change

text:
In popular culture, the climate fiction movie The Day After Tomorrow (2004) and the Al Gore documentary An Inconvenient Truth (2006) focused on climate change.
Significant regional, gender, age and political differences exist in both public concern for, and understanding of, climate change
label: Climate Change

text: More highly educated people, and in some countries, women and younger people, were more likely to see climate change as a serious threat
label: Climate Change

text: College biology textbooks from the 2010s featured less content on climate change compared to those from the preceding decade, with decreasing emphasis on solutions
label: Climate Change

text: Partisan gaps also exist in many countries, and countries with high CO2 emissions tend to be less concerned
label: Climate Change

text: Views on causes of climate change vary widely between countries
label: Climate Change

text: Concern has increased over time, to the point where in 2021 a majority of citizens in many countries express a high level of worry about climate change, or view it as a global emergency
label: Climate Change

text: Higher levels of worry are associated with stronger public support for policies that address climate change
label: Climate Change

text:
==== Climate movement ====

Climate protests demand that political leaders take action to prevent climate change
label: Climate Change

text: They can take the form of public demonstrations, fossil fuel divestment, lawsuits and other activities
label: Climate Change

text: In this initiative, young people across the globe have been protesting since 2018 by skipping school on Fridays, inspired by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg
label: Climate Change

text:
Mass civil disobedience actions by groups like Extinction Rebellion have protested by disrupting roads and public transport.
Litigation is increasingly used as a tool to strengthen climate action from public institutions and companies
label: Climate Change

text: Activists also initiate lawsuits which target governments and demand that they take ambitious action or enforce existing laws on climate change
label: Climate Change

text:
Lawsuits against fossil-fuel companies generally seek compensation for loss and damage.


== History ==


=== Early discoveries ===

Scientists in the 19th century such as Alexander von Humboldt began to foresee the effects of climate change
label: Climate Change

text: In the 1820s, Joseph Fourier proposed the greenhouse effect to explain why Earth's temperature was higher than the Sun's energy alone could explain
label: Climate Change

text: Earth's atmosphere is transparent to sunlight, so sunlight reaches the surface where it is converted to heat
label: Climate Change

text:
However, the atmosphere is not transparent to heat radiating from the surface, and captures some of that heat, which in turn warms the planet.
In 1856 Eunice Newton Foote demonstrated that the warming effect of the Sun is greater for air with water vapour than for dry air, and that the effect is even greater with carbon dioxide (CO2)
label: Climate Change

text:
She concluded that "An atmosphere of that gas would give to our earth a high temperature..."

Starting in 1859, John Tyndall established that nitrogen and oxygen—together totalling 99% of dry air—are transparent to radiated heat
label: Climate Change

text: However, water vapour and gases such as methane and carbon dioxide absorb radiated heat and re-radiate that heat into the atmosphere
label: Climate Change

text:
Tyndall proposed that changes in the concentrations of these gases may have caused climatic changes in the past, including ice ages.
Svante Arrhenius noted that water vapour in air continuously varied, but the CO2 concentration in air was influenced by long-term geological processes
label: Climate Change

text: Warming from increased CO2 levels would increase the amount of water vapour, amplifying warming in a positive feedback loop
label: Climate Change

text: In 1896, he published the first climate model of its kind, projecting that halving CO2 levels could have produced a drop in temperature initiating an ice age
label: Climate Change

text: Arrhenius calculated the temperature increase expected from doubling CO2 to be around 5–6 °C
label: Climate Change

text: Other scientists were initially sceptical and believed that the greenhouse effect was saturated so that adding more CO2 would make no difference, and that the climate would be self-regulating
label: Climate Change

text:
Beginning in 1938, Guy Stewart Callendar published evidence that climate was warming and CO2 levels were rising, but his calculations met the same objections.


=== Development of a scientific consensus ===

In the 1950s, Gilbert Plass created a detailed computer model that included different atmospheric layers and the infrared spectrum
label: Climate Change

text: This model predicted that increasing CO2 levels would cause warming
label: Climate Change

text: Around the same time, Hans Suess found evidence that CO2 levels had been rising, and Roger Revelle showed that the oceans would not absorb the increase
label: Climate Change

text: The two scientists subsequently helped Charles Keeling to begin a record of continued increase, which has been termed the "Keeling Curve"
label: Climate Change

text: Scientists alerted the public, and the dangers were highlighted at James Hansen's 1988 Congressional testimony
label: Climate Change

text: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), set up in 1988 to provide formal advice to the world's governments, spurred interdisciplinary research
label: Climate Change

text:
As part of the IPCC reports, scientists assess the scientific discussion that takes place in peer-reviewed journal articles.
There is a near-complete scientific consensus that the climate is warming and that this is caused by human activities
label: Climate Change

text: As of 2019, agreement in recent literature reached over 99%
label: Climate Change

text: No scientific body of national or international standing disagrees with this view
label: Climate Change

text: Consensus has further developed that some form of action should be taken to protect people against the impacts of climate change
label: Climate Change

text: National science academies have called on world leaders to cut global emissions
label: Climate Change

text:
The 2021 IPCC Assessment Report stated that it is "unequivocal" that climate change is caused by humans.
